actions-list.actionItem: Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 199, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Rose amendment No. 10.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Rose,  numbered 10 printed in House Report 118-7 to add a findings section that states that inspectors general should not less than annually for the next seven years publicly report the number of complaints and tips received, the number of investigations opened, and statistics on how investigations were managed and their disposition by that inspector general related to compliance with the underlying bill and the amendments made by the underlying bill.
On agreeing to the Rose amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 199, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Rose amendment No. 9.
An amendment, offered by Mr. Rose,  numbered 9 printed in House Report 118-7 to require mandatory annual training on the requirements of the underlying bill.
The House resolved into Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union for further consideration.

Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 140 â€” "To amend title 5, United States Code, to prohibit Federal employees from advocating for censorship of viewpoints in their official capacity, and for other purposes."
The House proceeded with one minute speeches which by direction of the Chair, would be limited to 15 per side of the aisle.

The House received a message from the Senate. The Senate passed S. 724, and H.J. Res. 26. Senate agreed to S. Res. 100. Appointments: Senate Trustee to the James Madison Memorial Fellowship Foundation and Board of Visitors of the U.S. Military Academy.
The Chair designated Mr. McGovern to lead the Members in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag.
The Speaker announced approval of the Journal. Pursuant to clause 1, rule I, the Journal stands approved.
Today's prayer was offered by the House Chaplain, Chaplain Margaret Grun Kibben.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of March 9.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for approximately 12:00 p.m. today.
The House proceeded with Morning-Hour Debate. At the conclusion of Morning-Hour, the House will recess until 12:00 p.m. for the start of legislative business.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Mary E. Miller to act as Speaker pro tempore for today.
The House convened, starting a new legislative day.
